page.title: 06Trees & Woods of Acklington
page.content:
There are many trees in Acklington Village. One of the oldest and most impressive is the large Chestnut on the east edge of the village, it is thought to be about 300 years old.
{Station Wood}is the largest wood in our area. It is owned by the Duke of Northumberland and is approximately 38 hectares in area. A team of woodmen look after the wood and plant new trees. The oldest trees in the wood are 79 years old and the youngest ones planted are only 3 years old. Trees in the wood include Scots Pine, Norway Spruce and Douglas Fir, as well as Oak, Beech, Sycamore, Willow, Birch, Ash and Holly. The wood used to be part of a Deer Park and indeed there are still a few Roe Deer living and roaming in the wood. There is a public footpath running through the wood.
